TITLE: The great crypto crisis is upon us
INTRO: Any regulation needs to look at what tangible economic benefits the industry actually offers
DETAILED_CONTENT: The writer is economic adviser and head of research at the Bank for International Settlements There is a bitter irony in the turmoil currently gripping the crypto universe. Crypto was born in the depths of the great financial crisis of 2008 as a backlash against the failings of the conventional financial system
TAGS: with its overleveraged shadow banks and daisy chain of leverage and maturity mismatch. The original Bitcoin white paper published that same year sold a vision in which money was refashioned as a self-sustaining system of peer-to-peer transfer without the need for intermediaries. However
AUTHOR_NAME: today‚Äôs upheaval bears all the hallmarks of precisely the failings that the industry‚Äôs early proponents railed against. As firms collapse and coin prices crash
CREATION_DATE: the unravelling of this new daisy chain of over-leveraged shadow crypto banks is now in full flow. While we survey the wreckage and plot a course for the policy response to rein in the sector
CATEGORY: we need to keep in mind some key facts. Crypto operates under the banner of decentralisation
column12: but it is highly centralised in two crucial respects. First
column13: many supposedly decentralised protocols turn out to be highly concentrated in terms of who actually governs and controls things. Often
column14: it is the founder and a small number of venture capital backers that are in charge ‚Äî as evidenced by the implosion of the Terra stablecoin in May. In most instances
column15: crypto is decentralised in name only. Second
column16: centralised intermediaries
column17: such as Sam Bankman-Fried‚Äôs FTX
column18: play a pivotal role as the gateway into the crypto world from the conventional financial system. They channel the flow of new investors
column19: which is the oxygen that keeps these speculative dynamics alive. BIS research in this area has highlighted how crypto only really works when this is happening. To the extent that recruiting new investors is key to the survival of crypto
column20: centralised intermediaries are crucial to propping up the edifice. The current collapse of FTX
column21: and other falling dominoes in the sector
column22: has led to much soul-searching among crypto promoters. Predictably
column23: we are hearing calls for the industry ‚Äúto go back to its roots‚Äù and be reborn in a purer form. The vision is to turn back the clock to the days when crypto was the preserve of a small group of enthusiasts rather than something marketed as a mainstream financial product. In this vision
column24: it would be more like a niche hobby among a small minority of followers
column25: rather than entering our living rooms through television advertising in an effort to draw in retail investors. This pure form of crypto
column26: which imagines getting rid of centralised intermediaries
column27: would have only a very small footprint. But crypto would not have grown to its current size without these entities channelling funds into the sector. Rather than standing in opposition
column28: centralised intermediaries and crypto feed off each other. For this reason
column29: any policy intervention now taken to mitigate crypto‚Äôs impact will need to take account of this mutual dependence
column30: as well as the role that stablecoins play as the gateway from the conventional financial system. Some say ‚Äújust let crypto burn‚Äù
column31: but the idea that it will disappear of its own accord may be wishful thinking. When financial conditions change
column32: even a much diminished sector that is the preserve of purists could still provide the embers for the renewed entry of centralised intermediaries. Any intervention would need to overcome one key challenge: if policy allows crypto to intertwine itself with the mainstream financial system
column33: it will usher in something that has been avoided so far. In particular
column34: if stablecoins are brought into the regulatory perimeter
column35: their role as the entry point to the rest of the crypto ecosystem will need to be addressed. Policy should guard against letting them become the ‚Äúcuckoo in the nest‚Äù. The new standards issued by the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision on banking sector activities in crypto are a significant step in the right direction. More generally
column36: the approach to regulation will need to distinguish the underlying economic function of crypto from what it looks like on the surface. Even during the worst excesses of the subprime mortgage boom
column37: the daisy chain of leverage ultimately led to real world activity ‚Äî most obviously buying a house with money. Crypto
column38: on the other hand
column39: is largely self-referential; its activities deal with trading other types of crypto and have little reference to tangible economic activity. Ultimately
column40: any public policy response needs to start with a realistic assessment of the economic value that flows from blockchain technology. Blockchain‚Äôs returns have been remarkably meagre considering the early hype. One after the other
column41: projects that have explored its potential benefits have come up empty-handed. A more promising approach is through central bank digital currencies that operate within the broader digital monetary system. This is an approach that builds on the trust embedded in central bank money
column42: and could serve public interest in a future monetary system. The technology benefits flow to real world economic activities rather than just other types of crypto. The economic benefits of decentralisation should also be scrutinised more effectively. We are now seeing what happens when an industry rests simply on an article of faith. TITLE: Time for a reset of the crypto opportunity
INTRO: Disruptive behaviour by some should not be allowed to spoil the opportunity in digital ledger technology
DETAILED_CONTENT: The writer is chief executive and president of BNY Mellon Events of the past few weeks offer a cautionary tale to anyone following the crypto space. Blockchain technology and its resulting cryptoassets were built upon the promise of a revolution in finance but
TAGS: amid the latest market disruption
AUTHOR_NAME: it‚Äôs time for a reset and review of the opportunity. Cryptocurrencies have dominated the headlines
CREATION_DATE: but they are a small part of the world of digital assets. To fully realise the untapped potential of the emerging digital asset ecosystem
CATEGORY: it is incumbent on leaders of the public and private sectors to work together to accelerate a smart regulatory framework that unites the traditional and digital asset systems
column12: rooted in two fundamental principles. The first is a recognition that regulation should enable the financial industry to prudently embrace innovation. Over the past two centuries
column13: the world has seen many generations of financial technologies. Digital ledger representations of traditional assets such as cash
column14: bonds and equities could be an important progression
column15: as the original computer ledgers and real-time payments were from paper before them. This can lead to improvements in accuracy of record-keeping
column16: easier handling of certain asset types such as real estate and loans and speedier
column17: more efficient settlement. The distributed ledger technology underlying cryptoassets can be used to underpin new market infrastructure that offers benefit to the financial system. The central bank digital currencies and tokenised bonds being explored by major jurisdictions are just a few examples of the efforts to harness the benefits of this new technology. Just last month
column18: the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and Monetary Authority of Singapore announced a joint effort to investigate how wholesale central bank digital currencies can improve the efficiency of cross-border wholesale payments involving multiple currencies. Exploration and innovation around digital ledger technology should thus be encouraged
column19: not punished
column20: in future regulatory frameworks. The second principle is to maintain the basic tenets of client protection
column21: orderly markets and clear regulatory guidelines ‚Äî regardless of the new technology
column22: asset class or type of entity servicing it. Our established frameworks for market health and safety in the US were borne out of a series of depressions. While the progression of banking and securities regulation has not always been linear
column23: it has remained rooted in these tenets. Digital assets operating outside those principles risk undermining the broader financial system. The fallout from co-mingled client assets
column24: poor disclosure and missing internal controls should remind us that while the cast of characters and products may change
column25: the script of financial market disorder remains painfully familiar. Although technology has evolved
column26: certain established concepts should apply to all market participants and assets regardless of their technological wrapper. These include good governance
column27: client asset segregation
column28: clear record-keeping
column29: security and technology standards
column30: capital and liquidity requirements
column31: limits on extreme leverage
column32: anti-money laundering protections
column33: strong risk management and regulatory guardrails. Today
column34: banking institutions already operate within a perimeter of regulation. While conferring both privileges and obligations
column35: this perimeter breathes what is arguably the most important currency into the global financial system: trust. Investor and public-sector confidence derive from the knowledge that the game has rules. Without trust in our financial system
column36: we will have nothing useful. Worse still
column37: without the resulting confidence in the system
column38: we may suppress the opportunity to embrace an exciting technology that could help move the industry forward. With a majority of institutional investors interested in tokenisation
column39: distributed ledger technology may represent the next financial frontier. Certain elements of the digital asset space have conflated disruptive innovation with generally disruptive behaviour
column40: but they should not be allowed to spoil the opportunity for everyone else. A comprehensive regulatory framework is needed
column41: but much of the underpinning already exists and can be extended from the regulation of traditional assets. There is a path to be found. We should embrace digital asset innovation
column42: and align it to established rules and measured regulatory principles in order to protect customers and promote resiliency. In so doing
column43: we also protect the most precious asset of all ‚Äî confidence in our financial system.

TITLE: The ‚ÄòMerge‚Äô did not fix Ethereum
INTRO: Switch in the way the blockchain works is leading to increasing centralisation of the network
DETAILED_CONTENT: The writer is professor of law at the American University Washington College of Law The Ethereum blockchain that facilitates much of the crypto world last month finally accomplished the long-promised and oft-delayed ‚ÄúMerge‚Äù
TAGS: a technical switch in the way it works. The Ethereum blockchain is one of the world‚Äôs most widely used digital ledgers
AUTHOR_NAME: and is the main platform for Web3
CREATION_DATE: non-fungible tokens
CATEGORY: and decentralised finance. While the Merge is unequivocally good news for the environment
column12: it brings the Ethereum blockchain‚Äôs other problems into even starker relief. Rather than relying on centralised intermediaries such as a bank to approve transactions
column13: blockchains rely on what is known as a ‚Äúconsensus mechanism‚Äù. Before the Merge
column14: Ethereum used the ‚Äúproof-of-work‚Äù consensus mechanism. This involves so-called ‚Äúminers‚Äù using enormous amounts of electricity to power computers to make repeated guesses of the number that will allow them to add a block of transactions to the blockchain. The winning miners are then compensated with cryptocurrency for their work. The bitcoin blockchain still does it this way. Verification of bitcoin transactions uses more energy than entire countries like Norway; in areas where lots of bitcoin mining occurs
column15: local populations have suffered from rising energy costs and noise pollution. Ethereum‚Äôs shift to a ‚Äúproof-of-stake‚Äù system avoids these environmental costs. Ethereum now uses an algorithm that randomly selects someone to create a new block to add to the blockchain. The party is chosen from those who have staked their ether (the Ethereum blockchain‚Äôs native coin) for the chance to do the work and be compensated for it. The more ether someone stakes
column16: the more likely they are to be chosen to create the new block. This creates incentives to acquire even more ether
column17: and it seems reasonable to predict that any blockchain that relies on proof-of-stake will start to concentrate the ability to process transactions in just a few hands. Staking is already a highly centralised business involving some of the industry‚Äôs largest companies
column18: such as Coinbase
column19: according to data provider Nansen. More centralisation seems inevitable. Remember that the whole point of having a blockchain with a consensus mechanism is to avoid having to rely on centralised intermediaries to verify transactions. Without meaningful decentralisation
column20: one has to wonder if all the other problems associated with Ethereum are worth it. For example
column21: the Ethereum blockchain is notorious for congestion at peak times
column22: which manifests in slower transaction processing times and fluctuating transaction fees (which are known as ‚Äúgas fees‚Äù). At peak times
column23: gas fees can be prohibitive for users trying to complete smaller transactions (in May 2022
column24: average daily gas fees reached nearly $200)
column25: but the Merge has not changed the way gas fees are calculated or charged. Such congestion adds to another problem. Users can pay validators higher fees to have their order executed first within a block of transactions. This is a cost on users which benefits the bigger validators which will be chosen to create more blocks of transactions
column26: and will therefore have more opportunities to pocket higher fees. A validator may even insert their own transaction ahead of others in order to profit from market movements
column27: a practice known as MEV or ‚Äúmaximal extractable value‚Äù. The Merge will also not make the blockchain more secure. Ethereum‚Äôs claims that it will do this assume that the Merge will increase decentralisation. But if the reverse is true
column28: there are risks. A report commissioned by the US Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency found proof-of-stake blockchains can be successfully manipulated if the number of validators is too small. The shift to proof-of-stake also increases the legal uncertainty around the status of ether. Prior to the Merge
column29: US Senator Debbie Stabenow proposed a bill that lists ether as an example of a ‚Äúdigital commodity‚Äù falling outside of the Securities and Exchange Commission‚Äôs jurisdiction (in the US
column30: securities are regulated by the SEC
column31: whereas the Commodity Futures Trading Commission has oversight over the commodities markets). However
column32: now that stakers pool their ether together in the hope of being compensated from the Ethereum blockchain‚Äôs gas fees
column33: a stronger case can be made that ether are securities and not commodities. The SEC might have something to say about Ethereum‚Äôs claims about its decentralisation and its benefits.
column35: Hilary Allen

TITLE: Web3: the future of the internet will not spell the end of Big Tech
INTRO: Walls are already being built before the tech utopia becomes a reality
DETAILED_CONTENT: The next iteration of the internet requires some magical thinking. Web3 is a tech utopia. It envisages a world of decentralised collaboration that would end the supremacy of major companies by wiping out lucrative markets for data collection and digital advertising. Yet building that world would require exactly the sort of investment that only Big Tech can provide. Hitting the refresh button on the internet looks tempting after years of disinformation and data hacks. First came the web ‚Äî a scattered collection of open-source information. Then came Web 2.0
TAGS: in which companies such as Google organised information and helped users to interact online while building walls around data. Tech giants amassed trillions of dollars of market value and now dominate the US stock market. Just five companies account for over a fifth of the S&P 500 index by market capitalisation. Web3 provides the backlash to this concentration of power. It is imagined as a decentralised system built on the blockchain in which companies no longer act as gatekeepers. User information will freely move across the internet. Instead of platforms making decisions about content
AUTHOR_NAME: users will self-moderate. Tokens will be generated as rewards and everything will be on public blockchains
CREATION_DATE: making the web transparent and safe. That is the theory anyway. Most of this does not yet exist. But the idea has gained momentum with the boom in newly fashionable non-fungible tokens (NFTs)
CATEGORY: digital ownership of online ephemera and decentralised finance projects running on public blockchains. Venture capitalists already use Web3 as a point of focus for investment in cryptocurrency projects. New VC fund Paradigm One raised $2.5bn in November to focus on applications that operate on ethereum. Its token ether now has a market capitalisation of more than $500bn
column12: up from $68bn a year ago. A planned upgrade from energy-intensive proof-of-work ‚Äî solving a math problem ‚Äî verification to proof-of-stake will raise ethereum‚Äôs profile further. Yet the end of Big Tech‚Äôs hegemony seems unlikely. The ethereum blockchain has limits on transactions and much of the public remains wary of digital tokens. Plus
column13: these wealthy companies have no plans to hand over control either. Social media platform Twitter has announced a dedicated crypto team. Facebook‚Äôs name change to Meta and plans to become a ‚Äúmetaverse company‚Äù are linked to the idea of a future in which digital assets can be moved safely around the internet. These early investments hint that new walls are being built before Web3 becomes a reality. For the latest news and views on fintech from the FT‚Äôs network of correspondents around the world

TITLE: China lays down challenge to the west on crypto

column12: deepening their engagement on regulatory and energy issues. They need to shift away from a ‚Äúzero-sum‚Äù mindset where their gains can only come from the losses of the established financial system. Overall
column13: the policy debate in western economies over crypto remains too narrow relative to the importance of the issues in play and excessively polarised
column14: with participants speaking different languages. This has intensified the underlying tug of war between accelerating private sector adoption and government/central bank discomfort. As the former steadily increases

column23: as well as China-US technological and economic competition. Three on-the-ground developments show how things are shaping up. First
column24: the technologies driving the crypto revolution
column25: including digitally-distributed ledgers of transactions known as blockchains
column26: are becoming more disruptive to a financial industry that has remained for too long relatively inefficient and a source of excessive profits. column27: despite their instability

column30: where too many traditional channels remain slow and expensive. But the broader evolution into global currencies continues to be undermined by price volatility
column31: lack of broad trust and regulatory concerns. The big question now in whether crypto disrupters and regulators in the West will succeed in converging on a more unified approach. The onus here falls primarily on the crypto world
column32: which risks repeating the mistake that Big Tech has made ‚Äî pursuing narrow business objectives without realising that their desired success will make them systemically important. For the latest news and views on fintech from the FT‚Äôs network of correspondents around the world

TITLE: Bitcoin 1.0: the ancient stone money of Yap

AUTHOR_NAME: the flamboyant founder of Tesla

This week it was equally striking that Citibank told its clients that the digital currency has reached a ‚Äútipping point‚Äù and could one day ‚Äúbecome the currency of choice for international trade‚Äù. Cue predictable levels of celebration from bitcoin-enthusiasts ‚Äî and of bemusement or horror from almost everyone else. Yet detractors and fans of the cryptocurrency both seem to agree on one thing: bitcoin is taking finance into the realm of bold 21st-century tech experiments. Is it though? On a week such as this
CATEGORY: it pays to take a wider historical lens ‚Äî and peek at nuggets from the past
column12: such as some research carried out in Micronesia by Scott Fitzpatrick
column13: an archaeologist at the University of Oregon
column14: and Oregon business school professor Stephen McKeon. The pair have been studying an ancient stone money system that once existed on the Micronesian island of Yap
column15: where local communities would treat large limestone discs as a medium of exchange. Such stone discs
column16: called rai
column17: ‚Äúwere considered extremely valuable‚Äù
column18: the pair noted in a 2019 paper in the Journal of Economic Anthropology. But the stones were so huge that ‚Äúgiven their size
column19: weight

But the local community maintained an oral ledger so effective in keeping track of who owned which hunks of immovable limestone that Fitzpatrick and McKeon concluded that rai were
column23: as a record of value
column24: ‚Äúan exemplary ancient analogue to blockchain‚Äù (the technology that powers bitcoin). Recommended Parallels between the two are limited. Limestone hunks cannot be subdivided as easily as bitcoin. And
column25: since blockchain ledgers are based on (seemingly) immutable computer code
column26: they appear more durable than communal memory. The circle of participants in bitcoin and blockchain deals is obviously exponentially larger than it was with rai ‚Äî and pseudonymous to boot. But there are other thought-provoking similarities between the two. First
column27: rai ‚Äî like bitcoin ‚Äî commanded value because of perceived scarcity; just as it now requires vast amounts of effort to ‚Äúmine‚Äù bitcoin (the technical term for the creation of new coins)
column28: so procuring rai was hard. The limestone discs were quarried from Palau
column29: 400km away from Yap
column30: then carried across the seas. This was the most impressive piece of maritime transport logistics seen in the region until the European explorers arrived in the 18th century and mind-bogglingly difficult for the time (although significantly less environmentally damaging than the filthy process of bitcoin mining
column31: which requires using huge amounts of electricity). The second point of similarity is that rai only functioned like money because there was communal trust. Unlike in the conventional modern monetary system
column32: the ‚Äútrust‚Äù underpinning rai did not operate in a vertical
column33: hierarchical manner ‚Äî ie
column34: due to faith in a leader or an institution; instead
column35: it was ‚Äúdistributed‚Äù horizontally. Everyone in the crowd needed to trust that everyone else would respect the oral ledger. Recommended Bitcoin also rests on the distributed trust of a crowd. For while computer code might seem impersonal
column36: free from capricious human intervention
column37: the system only works if people trust in the sanctity of that computer code. If that ever breaks down ‚Äî say because of a cyber hack or a shift in norms ‚Äî bitcoin would command even less value than rai does today. There is no sign that trust in blockchain is breaking down. Indeed

column41: the mainstream currencies on which our lives depend rely on sometimes tenuous social norms as well. One way to frame the contest between bitcoin and fiat currency is thus as a battle of norms ‚Äî and of distributed versus hierarchical trust. As the story of the rai shows

TITLE: China/blockchain: digital realm
INTRO: Investors seeking bitcoin exposure in local markets face constraints
DETAILED_CONTENT: Bitcoin is trading at a record high. Blockchain and cryptocurrency-linked stocks are posting record returns around the world. But not in China. Blockchain-related shares ‚Äî including companies that run digital currency trading platforms and cryptocurrency miners ‚Äî are regarded as an alternative to straightforward cryptocurrency investments. New York-listed Marathon Patent Group and Riot Blockchain are investor favourites. Both have gained more than 4
TAGS: 000 per cent in the past year. Yet the fortunes of Chinese blockchain-related companies have been mixed. Shenzhen-listed Brilliance Technology recorded gains of more than 44 per cent over a two-week span in early October as the current bitcoin rally kicked off. Shares of local peer Shenzhen Forms Syntron Information climbed in May before losing a third of their value the following month. For the full year
AUTHOR_NAME: the price is down 35 per cent. About half of the world‚Äôs bitcoin miners are Chinese. But investors looking for bitcoin exposure in local markets are constrained. Cryptocurrencies are not considered legal tender in the country. The People‚Äôs Bank of China has banned initial coin offerings ‚Äî cryptocurrency-based fundraising. It shut trading platforms four years ago. Unfavourable local regulations mean local companies closely linked to the mining and trading of cryptocurrencies have looked overseas to list in markets such as Hong Kong and the US. Recommended Locally listed crypto companies are largely focused on the development of blockchain technology for banking and commercial use. Demand for those services should rise as Beijing pushes ahead with its plans to encourage take-up of digital renminbi amid the pandemic. China has long wanted to replace cash. It also seeks to curtail the power of local fintech giants. The PBoC has distributed more than 100m worth of digital renminbi so far. Local blockchain companies should spy opportunities in systems development and support as the digital currency becomes more mainstream. The spur will be nothing like the bitcoin boom during the past few months. But it could be both more sustainable and less volatile. Lex recommends the FT‚Äôs Due Diligence newsletter

TITLE: By Jove! Crypto has discovered netting
INTRO: Why Bitcoin‚Äôs Lightning Network is just another pathway back to version 1.0 of the financial system.
DETAILED_CONTENT: Yes. The technical geeks will quibble with what we‚Äôre about to say. But conceptually and practically it amounts to this. End of. To get around its epic scaling limitations the numero uno cryptocurrency system (bitcoin
TAGS: duh) is finally deploying the Lightning Network (LN) to major players such as the exchange Bitfinex. And what that basically means is that bitcoin is moving firmly away from real time gross settlements and push payments and into the world of deferred net settlement and pull payments. An ironic state of affairs given its raison d'√™tre was to rid the world of intermediaries and reduce settlement risks and exposures. For a full account of how the Lightning Network really works
AUTHOR_NAME: it‚Äôs worth revisiting these essential Frances Coppola pieces (though be mindful that at the time they were written they upset many LN enthusiasts who couldn‚Äôt grasp the entirely accurate comparisons with conventional systems Coppola was making). The basic premise of LN is that regular transactions between two parties can be taken off the blockchain via the formation of a payment channel
CREATION_DATE: thus freeing up capacity on the main network. These are supposedly bonded structures to ensure the uncleared settlements are insured to some degree. Thus if two counterparts have an active two-way flow relationship between each other
CATEGORY: they need only ever settle the net differentials between them via the core chain on an infrequent basis. Obviously
column12: it‚Äôs not convenient in life to only transact with preapproved counterparties. But setting up a new channel with a new counterpart isn‚Äôt optimal either. Not only does it involve a transaction on the core chain (undermining the traffic decongestion objective of LN in the first place)
column13: it‚Äôs simply not practical. Thus the big idea in LN is that payments can be routed through preapproved channels until a pathway from you and your preapproved counterpart is found to your potential irregular recipient and their preapproved counterpart. But for that to work
column14: crypto payments undergo a major change in their dynamics. As Frances noted back in January 2018: Lightning is a ‚Äúpull‚Äù system. Every participant makes a payment
column15: then ‚Äúpulls‚Äù reimbursement from the previous participant. So each participant has to have sufficient ‚Äúown funds‚Äù in their channel to make the payment. If they don't
column16: they can't participate in the route
column17: and their predecessor must find a different participant. Using ‚Äúown funds‚Äù to make a payment on behalf of someone else meets the normal definition of ‚Äúlending‚Äù. It may be settled within milliseconds (or not
column18: as we shall see)

column20: via a network of other consciously coupled counterparts
column21: all respective counterparts need some base amount of liquidity at all times for the whole thing to square. Sound familiar? It does to us. We think what has inadvertently been reinvented is an intraday-liquidity dependent payment system
column22: within which liquid funds must not only be continuously present and unencumbered but extremely well distributed. A.k.a. the standing system of today
column23: complete with its massive dependence on intraday liquidity and bilateral bonded ‚Äúchannel‚Äù relationships (also known as repo). The difference

column26: when you look at payments systems like that for Fed funds

column28: as with LN

column30: settling only the very minimum via the core Fed system. This rings true for many other central banks operating real-time-gross settlement systems as well. As Daniela Gabor explained in her Alphaville piece about the evolution of the Tri-Party repo market: Banks rely on central bank money to manage the complex webs of settlement obligations resulting from their daily interactions with each other on behalf of retail and institutional clients. These obligations can be settled periodically on a net basis
column31: or immediately
column32: in ‚Äòreal time‚Äô on a gross basis. Banks prefer netting because it allows them to economise on central bank reserves

column34: they became increasingly dependent on access to Fed intraday overdrafts to bridge the temporary imbalances. To put that in crypto LN terms
column35: the common pathway between all the respective institutions making payments in the system became the Fed
column36: and it was de facto charged with plugging the gap when funding shortfalls emerged because in reality (due to the nature of life and trade) ‚Äúpathways‚Äù never squared up in time. By the late 1980s four clearing banks emerged as the most common ‚Äúpathway‚Äù counterparties
column37: who in turn had bilateral ‚Äútrusted‚Äù relationships with a plethora of other market players and so on. Like bitcoin enthusiasts
column38: the Fed also began to worry about its excessive ‚Äúintermediary‚Äù exposure to the system. To limit that exposure
column39: it started to charge fees for overdrafts. The market responded creatively. Salomon Brothers realised that if it normalised a tri-party repo structure ‚Äî essentially
column40: the use of a third common counterpart to intermediate settlements ‚Äî it could save fees by avoiding the Fed system entirely while reducing the risk of a funding shortfall. The problem is
column41: all the structure did was move the risk from the Fed to the tri-party clearing banks instead. The rest as they say (the global financial crisis

column45: sorry we mean the Lightning Network clearing
column46: occurs: Here‚Äôs a practical example of how a lightning network transaction functions. Alice opens a channel with her favourite coffee shop and deposits $100 worth of bitcoin in it. Her transactions with the coffee shop are instant because she has a direct channel with it. Bob
column47: who has a channel open with the grocery store he visits most frequently
column48: also buys coffee from Alice‚Äôs shop. The connection between Alice
column49: the coffee shop
column50: and Bob ensures that Alice can use funds from her balance with the coffee shop to buy groceries from Bob‚Äôs store. Similarly
column51: Bob can use his grocery store balance to conduct transactions with businesses in Alice‚Äôs network. If Bob closes his channel with the grocery store (and there are no other customers in common between the coffee shop and grocery store)
column52: then Alice will have to open another channel with the grocery store to make purchases there. In this way
column53: a web of transactions is created and routed between multiple lightning nodes in a decentralised fashion. The problems with this set up are clearly obvious to any core banking practitioner. 1) The system is massively credit dependent. 2) The system is extremely liquidity draining. 3) The system‚Äôs dependency on pre-funding is likely to be a huge deterrent to most users (do consumers really want a system that requires them to tie up funds with retailers they may or may not use?) 4) The system is hugely exposed to the coincidence of wants problem
column54: especially when it comes to getting funds out of the system and back into convertible bitcoin. This is because there is no mutual counterpart everyone has in common or has channels with
column55: but also because there is no compulsory clearing cycle. 5) To overcome the coincidence of wants problem the system will have to rely on an expansive pathway of pull-payments arrangement. This opens the system up to many as yet unknowable credit related risks. 6) Those funding the system and taking all that risk ‚Äî unlike in the conventional depositor-dependent banking sector ‚Äî get no return or reward for funding or providing liquidity to the system

column12: we hear you ask? Well
column13: it appears to be an Anglo-Spanish blog that offers cutting-edge commentary on the dollar and sometimes crypto
column14: like: Currently the general market has been changing and cryptocurrency calls have been changing the economy to be a new type of currency in which to bet. The dollar
column15: as always has been the strongest currency in the world

But the ‚Äúthe average lifespan of a fiat currency is 27 years‚Äù idea has been showing up around the sillier corners of the internet for several years now. Economist and blogger JP Koning has done a brilliant job of finding exactly where this meme originally came from
column17: and debunking it
column18: in a comprehensive blog post last month. As Koning points out
column19: the meme has been shared by a number of high-profile bitcoiners over the years
column20: including bitcoin developer Adam Back earlier this year
column21: and Barry Silbert
column22: one of the biggest crypto investors. Indeed
column23: as Koning pointed out on Twitter
column24: Silbert‚Äôs Grayscale investment group even uses it in its promotional material: Koning worked out that the meme had first appeared ten years ago (so just after bitcoin appeared on the scene)
column25: from a post by a guy called Matt Hewitt on Dollar Daze that has since been removed (you can still read it
column26: via the magic of the Wayback Machine
column27: here). The 27 Club But is there any truth in it? Or did the author just decide that it would be kind of neat for ‚Äúfiat currency‚Äù to join the 27 Club? First of all
column28: it‚Äôs important to get clear on exactly what a fiat currency is
column29: as there seems to be some confusion on this point. Bitcoiners tend to just use it as shorthand for central-bank-issued currency
column30: but actually it‚Äôs a little more nuanced than that. Here‚Äôs Koning: Fiat currency is generally considered to be inconvertible money. It can't be redeemed for gold or silver. The world really only shifted onto a fiat standard between 1968-71 as the dollar ceased to be redeemed in gold. But Hewitt's list is replete with many metallic currencies (i.e. the riksdaler riksmynt). Are people using his data to make a claim about currencies in general
column31: or just fiat ones? The meme isn't clear on this. But it does seem that Hewitt
column32: the originator of the meme
column33: did do some actual calculations to come up with the 27-year thing (albeit using some very selective methods). Hewitt claims to have counted 176 currencies that are still in circulation
column34: and 599 that aren‚Äôt. Koning downloaded the full list to check Hewitt‚Äôs calculations. It turns out that you can indeed arrive at an average ‚Äúlifespan‚Äù (more on that in a bit) of 27 years
column35: but that‚Äôs only if you make one fairly significant omission. Yup
column36: that‚Äôs right
column37: it only is true if you leave out all 176 currencies still in circulation. So... just a little misleading
column38: it seems fair to say. The other thing is that these 599 currencies that are no longer in circulation didn‚Äôt all just spontaneously combust
column39: as the meme implies. Rather
column40: they were actually deliberately replaced or ended for economic
column41: political or social reasons. So the idea of counting up these currencies‚Äô ‚Äúlifespans‚Äù just doesn‚Äôt really make much sense. From Koning again: The list contains all of the pre-euro currencies (Dutch gulder
column42: French franc
column43: Italian lira
column44: etc). These currencies had good reasons for disappearing: they were swapped for a new monetary unit. Existing currency holders weren't robbed. They were fairly compensated for this switch. Another example of monetary reorganization occurred in East Africa. From 1919 to the 1960s
column45: Britain's former east African colonies relied on the East African shilling
column46: produced by the East African Currency Board. When these countries gained their independence
column47: the currency board was dismantled. In its place Kenya began issuing its own shillings at par with the old ones
column48: as did Tanzania and Uganda. In each case
column49: existing owners of East African shillings could convert their holdings into new currency. No wealth was being destroyed during any of these switches. But people who throw around the phrase the average life expectancy for a fiat currency is 27 years as a criticism of the very institution of currency are using the data in a way that implicitly assumes that the East African experience--and others like it--were negative. They weren't. There are also some other factual errors that Koning points out -- the whole post is worth a read. So by this stage
column50: the 27-year life expectancy has been pretty comprehensively debunked. But what about the idea that bitcoin has now reached 40 per cent of that
column51: because it‚Äôs ‚Äúsurvived‚Äù ten or so years? That bit it also questionable. Has bitcoin actually successfully survived for ten years as a currency? One measure of success might reasonably be whether it has remained as one currency or whether it‚Äôs splintered off into different ones (because after all one of the things that gives currencies their value is some sort of scarcity). But bitcoin has ‚Äúforked‚Äù into different versions of itself twice already -- into bitcoin gold and bitcoin cash
column52: with the latter then splitting again to form bitcoin SV. So the people who originally backed bitcoin no longer agree on what the real bitcoin actually is. Adam Back might say it‚Äôs the thing most of us call ‚Äúbitcoin‚Äù (ticker: BTC); Roger Ver would tell you it‚Äôs bitcoin cash (BCH); while Craig Wright would tell you it‚Äôs bitcoin SV (BSV). Another measure of success of a currency might be its continued use as a medium of exchange
column53: and yet outside the dark net
column54: the acceptance of bitcoin in commerce has dried up (and that was from an already low base). Furthermore
column55: as we have said time and time again
column56: bitcoin is not a currency. It fulfils none of the three key criteria for being a currency (serving as a unit of account
column57: a medium of exchange
column58: and a store of value). So comparing it to currencies makes no sense. As we have also said before
column59: the fact that the battle cry of bitcoiners is HODL! is precisely why it makes no sense as a currency.

TITLE: Blockchain: disillusionment descends on financial services
INTRO: Too many projects started with the technology rather than the solution
DETAILED_CONTENT: Blockchain was going to make banks irrelevant and allow the world to ‚Äúbe [its] own bank‚Äù. Then
TAGS: it was going to help those very same banks save tens of billions of dollars a year in infrastructure costs

But despite a great deal of excitement ‚Äî and an even greater number of press releases ‚Äî the technology has not lived up to its promise and there are signs the hype is fading. Blockchain is the technology that underpins cryptocurrencies like bitcoin. It is
CATEGORY: in effect
column12: a database system that records and processes transactions via a distributed network of computers

column18: totalling some $1.7bn a year

column20: so far
column21: beyond the wild and volatile world of cryptocurrencies

column23: or a machine gun? You could do it

TITLE: Blockchain goes extra-terrestrial
DETAILED_CONTENT: An other-worldly blockchain press release crash-landed into the our inbox this week. It contained some somewhat sigh-enducing sentences such as: SpaceChain‚Äôs vision is to remove barriers and allow a global community to access and collaborate in space. And: Ultimately
TAGS: it will mean that there will be more opportunities for businesses/start-ups in the UK/EU to participate in the space economy
AUTHOR_NAME: thanks to blockchain. And: SpaceChain is a community-based space platform that combines space and blockchain technologies to build the world‚Äôs first open-source blockchain-based satellite network
CREATION_DATE: allowing users to develop and run decentralized applications in space. (Not
CATEGORY: apparently
column12: for all those times you‚Äôre hanging out in space trying to develop and run decentralised applications
column13: but rather for those times you‚Äôre hanging out on Earth thinking: ‚ÄúI‚Äôd like to run a decentralised application in space‚Äù.) But this doesn‚Äôt look like just another rip-off crypto project that‚Äôs about to rush off into outer space with all your money. SpaceChain has just announced that it has received funding from the European Space Agency
column14: no less
column15: under the agency‚Äôs ‚ÄúKick-start Activity‚Äù funding scheme. Just 60
column16: 000 euros
column17: but still
column18: this is Europe‚Äôs answer to NASA. Also the company‚Äôs CTO is the well-respected Jeff Garzik
column19: one of the early bitcoin developers. So we thought it would be worth trying to find out what this is all about. The Singapore-based company says that its purpose is ‚Äúto bring more security to the transmission of digital currencies and smart contracts by using a distributed satellite network and multi-signature transactions‚Äù. Ie
column20: it‚Äôs about making those famously ‚Äúunhackable‚Äù blockchains even more unhackable
column21: by putting some of the nodes (ie the connection points sitting inside computers that do the processing and maintaining of the transaction records) into space. SpaceChain says it has ‚Äúlaunched and flight-tested two blockchain nodes into space in the past 12 months‚Äù
column22: which are still orbiting Earth (!) and has even got what it says is a geospatial tracking feature that lets you watch the node orbit the earth in real time. We thought launching a satellite was quite expensive
column23: and probably outside the budget of a project like this. But according to Garzik
column24: there has been ‚Äúan exponential drop in the cost of access to space‚Äù
column25: with ‚Äúnanosatellites‚Äù like theirs being launched via ‚Äúride-sharing arrangements‚Äù (that‚Äôs rocket-ride arrangements
column26: FYI). The cost of doing this launching these 10cm cuboid nodes into space is therefore (rather perplexingly): Under $1M per launch
column27: trending towards under $300k. As for the reason for propelling these objects into Earth‚Äôs orbit
column28: Garzik explained: Having the node in space makes physical access to the node highly improbable which reduces possible attack vectors
column29: and independent space-base power supply and connectivity makes the blockchain infrastructure more robust. So maybe this all seems legit
column30: after all? Gives ‚Äúwhen moon?‚Äù a whole new meaning? It‚Äôs worth pointing out here that even though SpaceChain didn‚Äôt do a regular ICO
column31: it did run a ‚Äúprivate sale‚Äù of its tokens for institutional and accredited investors (which is what many in cryptoland now do because it gets you round pesky regulators‚Äô complaints about selling to unwitting retail investors). The token is now worth about a quarter of a cent on crypto markets
column32: having crashed by a
column33: er
column34: astronomical 99.5 per cent from a peak of almost 50 cents back in the crypto-manic days of early 2018. So moon might have to wait another day. But even if the project is legit and didn‚Äôt rip off retail investors
column35: that doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs not silly
column36: and indeed we can‚Äôt help feeling it‚Äôs all a little gimmicky. We thought the whole point of a decentralised distributed ledger -- and the geographical diversity inherent in that -- was to make attack vectors highly improbable. Also
column37: the idea is to create a multi-signature cryptocurrency wallet -- ie a crypto wallet that requires the signature of multiple private keys before funds can be transferred -- and for some of those of those private keys to be held in a satellite in outer space. But what happens if the satellites get damaged? Or if there‚Äôs some technical problem? Or if some bad actor attacks or takes possession of the satellites? They have a solution for that. Per the release: The funds in the wallet remain safe even in the event of a connectivity failure due to the fact that the two ground-based signatures can still complete the transaction. Ah yes. So you don‚Äôt actually need the extra-terrestrial satellite
column38: but it‚Äôs nice to have it. SpaceChain isn‚Äôt the first blockchain project seeking to go extra-terrestrial -- far from it. There have been a whole host of projects competing to advance blockchain in space
column39: like Nexus
column40: BitSpace
column41: Spacebit
column42: to name but a few. It‚Äôs also not the first company to think of putting a satellite into space to safeguard against earthly attacks -- a company called Cloud Constellation raised $100m at the end of last year to launch a network of data centres built on satellites in orbit

column44: like AWS or Mircrosoft Azure
column45: whose very business models depend on not having data breaches
column46: reckon that having a geographically diverse network of data centres on boring old Earth is secure enough. Attack of the 50-foot Blockchain author David Gerard sounds about as convinced by SpaceChain as us
column47: anyway: The idea is a dumb ICO idea of the sort that sounds like it was composed by sticking pins into a dictionary. The amazing bit is that they seem to be serious about it. I mean
column48: good luck to them
column49: but still nothing about this makes any sense. We‚Äôve updated this story since being told how much it does actually cost to launch blockchain nodes into outer space.

TITLE: Deutsche Bank joins JPMorgan-led blockchain network

TAGS: erm

Questions not yet answered include: 1) Would people banned from Facebook be able to use Calibra (the Facebook subsidiary that plans to offer payment services using Libra to users)? 2) Would people banned by Facebook ‚Äî in the envisioned fully permissionless future of Libra ‚Äî be able to acquire limitless nodes and thus potentially influence the network? 3) Would Facebook be free to rehypothecate assets acquired with customer deposits? And if so what risks does this pose? 4) Does anything stop Facebook from one day changing the rules about redeemability and/or the degree of collateralisation? But another central point being missed by many commentators is that as it stands Libra (and other cryptocurrency global currency replacement aspirants)
column12: are merely closed-loop systems. For a bit of background about the difference between closed and open-loop payments systems
column13: and the reason why credit is usually preferable in the latter
column14: see here. On that note
column15: we'd like to highlight the following points recently raised by Swift in an outline of their vision about how payments of the future should work (H/T Frances Coppola for bring this to our attention). With our emphasis: You can think of closed-loops as mini sovereign zones. Yes
column16: payments can be quickly and easily facilitated within those zones because everyone in them is subject to the same autocratic overseer and thus theoretically the same trust base. They're great if the overseer has large reach. But the problem which eventually emerges is that
column17: ultimately
column18: nobody wants a market dominated by just one payments overseer who can dictate what value gets to be transferred and to whom
column19: and what can't. Furthermore
column20: in a free market nothing stops another entity from launching a competing closed-loop system anyway. While we can agree that competition is a good thing in that context
column21: the problem with multiple closed-loops running side by side is that due to their intrinsic competitive nature (and different approaches to whom they let into their zones and how they manage risk within them) they don't interoperate easily. The inherent frictions between closed-loop systems (multiple sovereign states) is what brought about the need for open-looped solutions. Sticking with the sovereign metaphor
column22: opened-loop systems engineer the illusion of frictionless transfer with effective multilateral ‚Äútrade agreements‚Äù between all participant closed-loops systems in their network (which in the past included banks). The sovereignty clue was always in the name Visa. Once standard-based agreements have been forged between closed-loop ‚Äústates‚Äù
column23: all the respective members of those states can easily passport in and out of each other's zones. It's the equivalent of the free movement of people
column24: but in money terms
column25: based on the notion that everyone in the open-looped system is signed up to some basic common principles with respect to how they manage risk and who they are
column26: and are not
column27: prepared to bank. Hence why it's often difficult for challenger closed-loops systems to gain access to such multilateral transfer zones
column28: especially if they're coming to market on the basis they've found a way to bank people other closed-loop systems might avoid. The closed-loop/open-loop barrier exists on a national level
column29: but it's obviously even more pronounced on a cross-border basis. That's because on an international level it's not just a varying business model that undermines the uniformity of the respective interoperating closed-looped systems. It's also law
column30: the manner in which the law is enforced
column31: culture
column32: governance
column33: tax
column34: attitude to protectionism ‚Äî to name a few. In other words
column35: it's exactly the same sort of stuff posing cross-border costs and frictions that poses costs and frictions when it comes to free and interoperable trade. Bear that in mind with the following points raised by SWIFT (with our emphasis): SWIFT understands the political reality of why cross-border payment frictions exist. They're not technical problems
column36: they're political problems. Facebook's Libra initiative in that context implies two very concerning things. The first is that Facebook ‚Äî despite all its access to capital and talent ‚Äî possibly doesn't understand the basic problem it is trying to solve. If that's the case
column37: that suggests it's not a business worth investing in. The second ‚Äî possibly more alarming thing ‚Äî is that Facebook does understand this
column38: but it doesn't care. And that's because it's objective isn't building an open-loop decentralised system
column39: but quite plainly

column41: politically and financially
column42: into its holistic and autocratic system. James Bond movies were made about far less audacious global domination plans.

TITLE: How blockchain takes us back to medieval times
INTRO: History teaches us that when credit systems are replaced with payment systems
DETAILED_CONTENT: economies are starved of liquidity.
TAGS: The marketing spiel about blockchain distributed ledger technology (DLT) often promises to liberate financial institutions from the costly burden of having to pledge billions of dollars in margin to clearing houses on the basis that trades complete instantaneously
AUTHOR_NAME: meaning counterparty risks are eliminated. But this
CREATION_DATE: according to a new report by Greenwich Associates' Ken Monahan
CATEGORY: is a wrong-headed way to think about things. Monahan
column12: who in other respects is quite complimentary of DLT
column13: notes that in most cases those savings arguments are moot. This is because what real-time gross settlement of securities offers with one hand it simultaneously takes away many times over with the other hand in terms of pre-funding costs. This
column14: incidentally
column15: is a point the FT's Philip Stafford has made to FT Alphaville in conversations around the hypothetical FT water cooler ever since the industry started going mad about the potential of DLT. Or as Monahan puts it: Using DTCC as an example
column16: real-time clearing could theoretically save $8bn in reserve funds. But what that also means is that all participants would have to pre-fund (or even over-fund in a volatile market) all prospective trades fully before being able to execute them. There are two issues in play here. One: in a DLT real-time framework all trades become bilateral rather than multilateral
column17: which makes the savings from margining impossible. Two: in a DLT real-time framework there is no netting. As a result the system requires all transactions to be fully funded on a transaction by transaction basis. According to Monahan that takes the system back to the era before the New York Stock Exchange Clearing House enabled marketwide net settlement in 1892. But that's not even how far back in time DLT takes us. Even in 1891 an investor could secure a call loan against shares during the day it took to settle them
column18: says Monahan. This is impossible to do with instantaneous settlement. You simply cannot use shares you have yet to transact as collateral for a loan. Thus trades not only have to be pre-funded
column19: they need to be pre-funded on an unsecured basis. Consider the relevant mechanics thusly (from the report
column20: with our emphasis): All of which takes us not just back to 1891 but to 1584
column21: when the Venetian Senate decided to require pre-funding of all trading done via the Banco di Rialto following the collapse of the Venetian banking system due to the bankruptcy of a number of merchant houses which had used aggressive and high-risk ledger accounting techniques. Problem is
column22: the Senate's solution soon began to choke the entire economy. Here's the story via Monahan (our emphasis): Which is another way of saying: be careful what you wish for. DLT is in effect
column23: an extremely narrow banking model. It's not clear at all if that is desirable for an expanded and globalised economy that depends on credit extension at every commercial interaction point. TITLE: Cryptocoin computer code fails to deliver on promoter claims
INTRO: Marketing for currency offerings promise investor protections that the assets do not deliver
DETAILED_CONTENT: Between 2016 and 2018
TAGS: cryptocurrencies produced a bona fide financial bubble. Nothing typified the madness better than the craze for initial coin offerings meant to fund software projects that promised to revolutionise everything from online gaming to file storage. Maybe you invested. More likely
AUTHOR_NAME: you intuited something was awry when your Uber driver started asking for crypto recommendations and a friend began touting a blockchain-based ledger designed to track marijuana supply chains. CREATION_DATE: regulators at the US Securities and Exchange Commission are having to grapple with the problems caused by these investments. So far
CATEGORY: the watchdog has focused on bringing ICOs under its traditional regime of disclosure-based investor protection rules. But my research with David Wishnick into the ICO market reveals some disquieting facts. The central innovation in ICOs rests on the possibility of using computer code to deliver on contractual promises. So we surveyed the 50 offerings that raised the most capital in 2017 and asked a simple question: did the promoters deliver on their promises to protect investors through computer code? We specifically compared the promises promoters made in their offering documents with the actual function of the cryptoassets they delivered. We audited each coin‚Äôs smart contract

TITLE: SEC must solve its cryptocurrency custody conundrum
INTRO: Too much regulation may stifle innovation but too little will put Main Street investors at risk
DETAILED_CONTENT: As blockchain technology grows in popularity
TAGS: the US Securities and Exchange Commission faces a conundrum: how should it regulate the safekeeping or custody of a digital asset owned by an investment fund or managed account? To solve this puzzle
AUTHOR_NAME: the regulator has to reconcile decades-old laws with new and inherently risky technology. Too much regulation may stifle innovation but too little will put Main Street investors at risk. Doing nothing is not an option. Current law requires mutual funds to deposit securities and similar assets in a vault or other depository belonging to a bank or trust company. Registered investment advisers must also maintain client assets with a qualified custodian. The law stops short of specifying how a custodian bank must safeguard
CREATION_DATE: or maintain custody of
CATEGORY: a client‚Äôs assets. Distributed ledger technology such as blockchain presents a novel challenge: how can a custodian
column12: or an auditor
column13: be certain that the custodian actually has possession of a digital asset? In theory
column14: the answer is simple. To prove ownership of a digital asset
column15: such as bitcoin
column16: you must have both a public key and a corresponding private key. The public key appears as a string of digits representing a unique transaction that is added on as a block in a chain of other transactions. The private key
column17: however
column18: is a string of digits that is intended to be kept secret
column19: a sort of electronic bearer instrument. Whoever has the private key can transfer a digital asset immutably and potentially anonymously to anyone. The SEC‚Äôs challenge is to ensure that such digital assets cannot be stolen or misappropriated. The answer may involve a combination of physical and electronic solutions
column20: and some creative legal thinking. Some banks assert that they have developed platforms and procedures to keep digital assets safe. These may include holding digital assets in an offline wallet rather than on an exchange
column21: requiring multiple electronic signatures to obtain access to the private key and keeping the private key on a computer in a physical vault ‚Äî without an internet connection ‚Äî to prevent criminals hacking in. As there is no single answer to what kind of security is sufficient
column22: the SEC should take a balanced
column23: practical approach. It should not try to prescribe specific technological standards because what is appropriate for one custodian may not work for another and today's state-of-the art requirements may become rapidly outdated. Regulations should require custodians to embrace technology that is sufficient to provide adequate security
column24: coupled with robust and ongoing testing
column25: similar to how financial intermediaries test for the adequacy of cyber security protections. The SEC could also treat all ‚Äî or certain categories of ‚Äî digital assets as securities solely for purposes of the custody rules
column26: without determining whether they are securities that must be registered for sale. This approach would provide some certainty on the application of the custody rules. This would be welcome as some senior SEC staff have suggested that some digital assets that are securities may morph into non-securities and vice versa. Bitcoin
column27: for example
column28: is generally thought not to be a security
column29: but certain non-fungible tokens
column30: such as CryptoKitties
column31: may morph into securities depending on how their functions change over time. The SEC could also establish robust standards for safekeeping programmes. These could include internal control reports and compliance testing. It could also consider a backstop that would involve special capital requirements or a form of third-party insurance to protect digital assets. But the SEC will never be able to eliminate digital asset fraud
column32: just as it cannot eliminate other forms of theft. No matter how many protections are required
column33: the first time that a bad actor empties the digital wallet of an investment account
column34: everyone ‚Äî including the press and Congress ‚Äî will point fingers at the SEC for failing to require sufficient safeguards. Yet
column35: by considering novel regulatory approaches adapted to the risks inherent in digital assets
column36: educating investors
column37: holding market participants to high standards and vigorously prosecuting bad actors
column38: the SEC has the power to nurture technological innovation while still protecting Main Street investors. Jay G Baris is a partner at Shearman & Sterling

TITLE: A fraud or the future? Bots and the bitcoin debate
INTRO: For sceptics
DETAILED_CONTENT: bot activity will be further evidence of cryptocurrencies‚Äô failings
TAGS: Last year
AUTHOR_NAME: I took part in a noisy public debate about whether bitcoin is a beneficial innovation ‚Äî or the opposite. It was an eye-opening experience: almost as soon as the event was posted online
CREATION_DATE: I was trolled by furious cryptocurrency fans and critics alike. Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies such as ethereum
CATEGORY: I concluded
column12: arouse a level of passion rarely found within finance. Their detractors are convinced that the entire concept is a fraud; their evangelists are equally certain that cryptocurrencies are the future. Both sides may be right
column13: depending on timing. Presently
column14: cryptocurrencies seem to be marred by intellectual contradictions. Why does anyone think
column15: for example

column18: 000 in the past 18 months? But I also recognise that the underlying blockchain technology is potentially very useful. It is entirely possible that future historians might see bitcoin as the MySpace of cryptocurrency ‚Äî a pioneering product that was flawed but eventually replaced by better versions of the technology. However
column19: if you want to get a less emotional view of these issues
column20: consider a fascinating study of crypto trading that has just been conducted by an eight-strong team of computer scientists based at institutions including Cornell Tech
column21: Carnegie Mellon University
column22: the University of Illinois in Urbana Champaign and ETH in Zurich. Their research set out to determine whether trading in cryptocurrencies is fair when it takes place on decentralised exchanges (DEXes)
column23: where individual traders cut deals directly with each other in a relatively transparent way
column24: without a central authority. Before the study
column25: it might have been expected ‚Äî or hoped ‚Äî that these venues were indeed pretty fair. After all
column26: the whole point of cryptocurrencies is that they enable ‚Äúminers‚Äù to create ‚Äúmoney‚Äù and for it to be priced in a peer-to-peer manner with a permanent digital record. Central banks
column27: governments and other institutions are not involved: call it digital people power. It is true that shady things have occurred when cryptocurrencies have gone on to exchanges: just last month
column28: for example
column29: a computer analytics group called The Tie calculated that ‚Äú87 per cent of exchanges reported trading volume was potentially suspicious
column30: and that 75 per cent of exchanges had some form of suspicious activity occurring on them‚Äù. But cryptocurrency advocates argue that the gains from democratising money outweigh such apparent abuses. However
column31: when the researchers started tracking the DEXes (six of them
column32: over 18 months) they had a nasty surprise: they found that the networks have become infested by computer bots
column33: operating alongside the libertarian humans who are meant to populate them. More specifically
column34: some unscrupulous miners and traders have apparently created these bots to anticipate and gain from others‚Äô everyday trades by gaining advantages in the platforms‚Äô information flows
column35: enabling them to siphon off millions ‚Äî or even billions ‚Äî of dollars a year in profits. ‚ÄúLike high-frequency traders on Wall Street
column36: these bots exploit inefficiencies in [DEXes]
column37: paying high transaction fees and optimizing network latency to front-run trades
column38: ‚Äù the research paper declares. ‚ÄúWe observe bots competitively bidding up transaction fees in order to obtain priority ordering.‚Äù Translated for the lay reader
column39: what this means is that some ruthlessly aggressive traders are finding ways to grab data on the deals that other investors are trying to cut ‚Äî and then jumping ahead of them to take advantage of the prices. To be fair
column40: crypto is not alone in this respect. As Michael Lewis‚Äôs book Flash Boysexplained a few years ago
column41: high-frequency traders have been using bots to front-run other investors in the equity world for several years. Moreover
column42: the scale of this bot activity is probably still small when viewed against the wider financial system. Nevertheless
column43: there are two reasons why this tale is striking. First
column44: it shows the difficulty of ever trying to build a truly democratic marketplace ‚Äî with bitcoin or anything else ‚Äî in a world of accelerating (and unequal) computing power. Second
column45: it also shows the challenges of cleaning up this corner of finance. Thus far
column46: regulators have shown little sign of being heavy-handed in their crypto regulation
column47: preferring to rely instead on the principle of caveat emptor. Besides
column48: very few crypto enthusiasts are asking for regulation (partly because they tend to dislike government intervention in any form). But can a fledgling product such as bitcoin truly flourish if there is no external oversight? Can investors find a way to clean up their marketsthemselves? Right now it is unclear. However
column49: the next time you meet a crypto evangelist
column50: point out the odd story of the blockchain bots ‚Äî or direct them to the webpage that the researchers have provided
column51: which tracks the bots in real time. If nothing else
column52: it should spark more debate ‚Äî and possibly another bitcoin row. Follow Gillian on Twitter @gilliantett or email her at gillian.tett@ft.com Follow @FTMag on Twitter to find out about our latest stories first. Subscribe to FT Life on YouTube for the latest FT Weekend videos

column13: it is worth dwelling on the features that make fiat money ‚Äî what states declare to be legal tender ‚Äî so potent. Fiat money works because it is issued by a power that: has tax-raising powers; can pay interest; can achieve productivity in the form of trade; has a monopoly on minting new money; supports all of this with the legitimate use of physical force (through writing laws and raising an army); and is recognised by other nation states. column14: the more societal trust there is in fiat money as a store of value. Libertarians and cyber utopians

column17: in contrast to fiat money
column18: cryptocurrencies are a claim on nobody

column23: it has established itself as a store of value globally and over millennia. The notion that a cryptocurrency‚Äôs value might be tied to the success of blockchain is just as contentious. Blockchain may generate some utility in the form of improved security and reduced transaction costs
column24: and may even prove to be transformative at some stage. But it does not follow that the tokens used to support transactions should be elevated to the status of tradable currency and positioned as a store of value
column25: or worse still

column27: asset-backed tokens ‚Äî a digital version of the chips used in casinos ‚Äî stand a better chance of prevailing in the longer run. As an asset or a currency

column25: FundsDLT and Amun ‚Äî that are beginning to figure out how to apply smart contracts and DLTs to the fund admin chain. Swiss-based Amun for instance has been quietly building a full-stack fund admin structure that could be used with outside firms ‚Äî it was forced to build these multiple functions so as to launch its own physically-backed crypt tracker. FundsDLT has also worked with Amundi

Along the way we could see costs reduced and efficiency vastly increased with T+0 (same-day trade settlement) theoretically possible. There are already businesses building DLT-based architecture. Challenges remain: regulators will need to get behind these ideas
column30: but the way in which central banks have begun to seriously consider digital ledgers ‚Äî for emoney versions of fiat money ‚Äî suggests that their bureaucratic minds may be open to the possibilities of blockchain. It is also true that the technology is not user-friendly and is vulnerable to tech-savvy manipulation. Open access to the transaction and settlement blocks scares many while even more insiders worry about scalability ‚Äî my guess is that leviathans such as State Street or BNY are not quaking just yet. Looking even farther out
column31: another vista appears: the tokenisation of most fungible assets. I would be a rich man now if I had received ¬£1 for every opportunity spun to me about tokenising an office building (or expensive violin or bottle of precious French wine). A few projects have emerged in the US

column34: that could change; even better if the smart contracts sitting under the bonnet help cut costs (especially magic-circle legal costs) and result in access to new alternatives. This brings me to my last contrarian thought. Could a progressive regulator mandate a wholesale move to blockchain?
